Hi,
just watched this video about human genes:
http://www.youtube.com/watch=
?v=3Dyr428fhp64I

it says that:
an amoeba has 4,000,000 genes
a grain of ri=
ce has around 40,000 - 50,000 genes
and a human genome has around 25,000 ge=
nes.

also i have found (http://en.wikipedia.org/wiki/Junk_DNA/) that 95% o=
f genes in human genome are junk (like disabled genes in NEAT?) 
So, a wort=
hful ammount of gene in a genome would be around 1,250 genes?

How it is po=
ssible, that a complex specie like human being has so little genes and a pr=
ehistoric amoeba has so many genes? 
The only conclusion i can make from he=
re, is that instead of starting from a null genome and increase the number =
of genes we should start with a lot of random genes and work on methods to =
reduce the number of genes while conserving the same(or increasing) fitness=
.
Or, we should start with null genome and grow the genome until the fitnes=
s stops improving, and then work on optimization of the genome until genome=
 is reduced in size, when genome is not reduced anymore, we should start ad=
ding genes again.

Just an idea.
